item.title: Finding time for creative work.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: Finding time to do creative work is something we all struggle with. Whether it's drawing pictures or solving business problems, most everyone I know wishes they had more free-thinking time to  produce really great work. Instead of just pushing out mediocre stuff to meet a deadline. I often lament about my lack of open, uncommitted time. The kind of time needed to do the thinking that leads to high-quality ideas.  I also get frustrated by time lost to interruptions when I do find a few daylight hours to do focused creative work. This morning a great article landed in my in-box, called Getting Creative Things Done: How To Fit Hard Thinking Into a Busy Schedule. Written by Cal Newport, the article suggests creative thinkers use the GCTD (Get Creative Things Done) system. It's an adaptation of another system proposed by Paul Graham in his essay Maker's Schedule. Manager's Schedule. I remember reading Graham's essay a few months ago. His insights rang true for me, but I haven't had the discipline to implement his recommendations. Though, in small ways I have tried. If you struggle to balance creative work with your to-do list, and who doesn't, give these articles a read. I think you'll find refreshing and powerful ideas in both. They're worth the time. ================ Thanks to @the99percent for sending the email that inspired this post.

item.title: The benefits of full-immersion, bilingual education.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Three years ago my wife and I decided to enroll our daughter at Denver Montclair International School, a full-immersion, bilingual ECE and elementary school. There are lots of reasons for our choice, but chief among them are the opportunities that come from a broader based of experience and knowledge.
Studies show that bilingual children are more creative and flexible problem solvers who consistently demonstrate advanced analysis and comprehension. Their ability to communicate freely in two or more languages gives them much broader perspective and greater insight into the interconnectedness of world cultures. It also provides tremendous educational, professional and life opportunities. Christie Thurstone, Media Salad
Since making that choice we've become staunch advocates for bilingual education and school programs which teach global citizenship. Our studio has also developed this as an area of expertise—we now have two international schools as clients. Our partner in education marketing is Media Salad, a remarkably skilled market intelligence and research company that advocates for bilingual education. Here's a post about the benefits of language written by Christie Thurstone, CEO of Media Salad. For it, she used Storify, a new digital curation tool we're both testing.

item.title: Optimistic or Pessimistic - U.S. CFO Survey
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
FastCompany.com today published a detailed, interactive graphic based on data from a GE survey of U.S. CFOs. The graphic was create by Lisa Strausfeld and Pentagram.
GE has just published its latest interactive infographic, which presents the results of a massive survey asking 530 CFOs how confident they were in the present economic recovery. Since it's gauging the subjective viewpoints of these CFOs, you get a little bit of insight into to how they feel -- and how collective emotions help shape our economy.
While exploring the graphic I was surprised by the level of detail the designer achieved through drill-downs into the data categories. I particularly liked the view by industry selector at the top which updates the data visualization instantly. Like anything useful, it took me a few clicks to learn the mechanics of interface. But I'm of the opinion that a user interface does not need to be dumbed down unitl a monkey could use. If the information you're presenting has value, it's fair to expect some learning on the part of the user. This is a great graphic for information design geeks and economic news junkies alike. The article on FastCompany.com The interactive graphic on GEblogs.com.

item.title: If you're not failing, you're not designing.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_1069" align="aligncenter" width="478" caption="Image from Till Grushe, frog design"][/caption] One of our guiding principles at Hero is Design Thinking. An idea originally written about by Roger Martin in his book The Design of Business. Tim Brown, of IDEO, has pushed the idea forward, adding significantly to the conversation with his article in the HBR, IDEO's Design Thinking blog and a body of work that demonstrates this abstract idea in real-world projects. Tim describes Design Thinking as:
Design thinking can be described as a discipline that uses the designer’s sensibility and methods to match people’s needs with what is technologically feasible and what a viable business strategy can convert into customer value and market opportunity.
One of the tenants of Design Thinking, and most agile creative processes, is to fail fast. To prototype rapidly, iterate your design and discover problems along the way, not on your ship date. It's a myth that great design, of any kind, comes in a lightning flash of inspiration. Great design is the result of a process where the majority of effort, results in failure. It's only the last, best effort that the world sees.

Fail Forward

Till Grushe, of frog design, recently led a "Fail Camp" where he, and several other design leaders, "discussed how failing relates to innovation, share insider-experiences with the audience about failed innovation projects and the best practices companies can harvest from failure and succeed from learning." Till captured the experience in this blog post, along with his insights on the challenges of bringing the "fail forward" idea into a corporate culture.
Failcamp @ trendforum 2010
View more presentations from frog design.

item.title: Twitter vs. Facebook - By the numbers.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
In the daily rush of social media we often can't see the big picture. We can't see just how many people are involved in these online tools. And we can't see just who they are. Well the big picture just got a little clearer thanks to the folks at Digital Surgeons. I see a lot of parody in the two platforms…
  • U.S. awareness levels for both Twitter and Facebook are in the high 80s.
  • Gender numbers are nearly identical.
  • Income distribution is vary similar.
And a few big differentiators.
  • 41% of Facebook users login everyday, compared to only 25% on Twitter.
  • 52% of Twitter users update their status everyday, compared to only 12% on Facebook.
  • 29% of Facebook users are 18-25, compared to only 18-25 on Twitter.
And of course the gorilla in the room is the total number users— Facebook has 500 million, Twitter has only 106 million.

What does all this mean?

I think this shows what many followers of social media already know.
  • Facebook is a platform more likely to see passive consumption of media.
  • Twitter is fueled by content creation and discovery.
  • Twitter use is driven by intellectual desire.
  • Facebook is driven by emotional desire.

How does a marketer make use of this info?

With the demographics of Facebook and Twitter being largely similar, marketers need to focus on their function to make the best of both. Use Twitter as a micro-broadcasting platform to draw people to the content you create. Use it also to talk 1-to-1 with prospects, clients and thought leaders. Facebook is a richer canvas where you can promote the culture of your organization or your product. Advertising on Facebook is a great way to reach targeted demographics you believe will Like your content the most. Facebook's richer experience makes it inherently more emotional, so use that to your advantage—be authentic and be expressive. In both platforms, keep the canned PR and sales messages to a minimum.

item.title: The Gabby Gourmet Guide iPhone App
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: Today we're celebrating the release of Hero's first iPhone app - The Gabby Gourmet Guide. We created this app in partnership with our long-time client Pat Miller, the Gabby Gourmet. Gabby is Colorado's most trusted restaurant reviewer and advocate for dining out. item.title: Clients Embracing the Lean UX Evolution
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Lately I've begun having conversations with clients, current and prospective, about iterative design processes. For clients who are on the front side of the curve, this topic is showing up on their radar. Designers should take note as this presents an opportunity to exercise thought leadership with clients and move some of them into a more efficient and rewarding design process.

One bit of insight I've been sharing with these clients is Jeff Gothelf's excellent article Lean UX: Getting Out Of The Deliverables Business. From a combination of intuition and necessity our design process at Hero has been getting leaner and leaner. A heavy workload and the need for speed has caused us to lighten our project documentation and move more quickly into wireframes and prototypes. For personal projects we have been skipping the documentation and wireframing steps all together, jumping from the whiteboard straight to prototypes. So far, working this way has  created some solid successes with no major failures. And moving fast & light feels great. Now that the conversations are starting, we're looking forward to taking more of our lean process into our client work. Check back with us in a couple months to hear more about our experiences.

item.title: COMMON Capitalism. AIGA Sustainability.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: The time is nearing the end for the current form of capitalism practiced in industrialized nations. It is no longer the positive force it once was and the world's ecosystem is groaning under its weight. COMMON describes the imperative this way—our model for capitalism must move: from DISPOSIBILITY  to SUSTAINABILITY from SECRECY to TRANSPARENCY from COMPETITION to COLLABORATION COMMON has a big idea and framework to achieve it. Learn more about it here. =========================================================== Another great movement is AIGA's sustainability initiative called The Living Principals. The Living Principles for Design aim to guide purposeful action, celebrating and popularizing the efforts of those who use design thinking to create positive cultural change.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: It sounds interesting.

item.title: Mistakes Marketers Make: Audience
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
As a marketing agency, there are a few mistakes we see clients make again and again. These mistakes, and or mis-conceptions, underlie their strategies, planning and tactics. Over the next few weeks we'll cover a few of them.

You Don't Have An Audience. You Have A Metaphor.

Marketers often talk about the people for whom they're creating their campaigns as the audience. But this is a mis-conception. There is no audience. We only use that word as a metaphor. In marketing, the metaphor leads us to think there are  people out there anxiously waiting to watch our video, read our blog, attend our webinar. But they are not. Marketing is an interruption. Nobody buys a ticket to see it. If you want your message to be heard, it will have to earn people's attention. How do you earn people's attention and build a real audience? Great ideas expressed in great content. Think Glee. More on content in the near future. This post was inspired by thoughts from Faris Yakob.

item.title: Better Logos don't Make Better Coffee...or a better place to gather
item.dc:creator: Jeff

Yes the Starbucks logo as been out for a while now, but we at Hero love coffee too much not to mention it. Whether it’s an embarrassing decaf chi frapp or a manly-man’s double shot of espresso, the heavenly beans are part of our lives, daily...right around 3pm to be exact.
However beautiful the new siren may be though, she does not produce our favorite coffee. We prefer the style and flavors of Novo Coffee provided to us by our friends at Fluid Coffee Shop in Uptown.
If you love coffee as much as we do, please join us this Friday, March 18th for the grand opening of Fluid’s new addition–Fluid Meeting Spaces, a new flexible work space where people can meet, collaborate, braidstorm, and host events.
Hero Design Studio has partnered with Fluid to develop the branding, website, and scheduling web app for the new expansion. We are also excited to be involved in Meeting Spaces as a Community Sponsor, donating meeting hours for local non-profits and groups to hold gatherings.
For more information on holding a meeting or becoming a Community Sponsor, please visit www.fluidmeetingspaces.com.

item.title: Task Rabbit - Outsource your errands.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
If you thought all the great web service ideas have been done already, you're wrong. Check out TaskRabbit.  A service for crowd-sourcing your errands to pre-approved runners. Through the TaskRabbit site you post your task, select the runner, from those who bid on it, give detailed instructions and pay for the transaction. It looks like you can even earn points for frequent use.

The goal, I assume, is to help people be more productive. As a guy who is frequently watching the bottom line, I can see the value of hiring someone to handle simple, non-revenue generating tasks. Wait…isn't that what interns are for? I guess they've got some new competition. If TaskRabbit ever reaches Denver, we'll give it a try. BTW - I really dig the video integration on the home page. A nice usability feature we'll put in our back-pocket for a future project.

item.title: Social Media, a Force for Good
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: The evolution of social media is always an fascinating subject for me. Something that started out–for the most part –with people sharing casual, unimportant information such as the ham sandwich I’m having for lunch, has evolved so much further in the last six years. The most amazing thing though is how social media has turned into such a prominent way for us to share valuable information. One can use Twitter solely to follow news  on just one topic and see more tweets in a day than can be red. This is probably where you’re thinking, “This isn’t a new idea; blogs have been discussing this for a while now,” and yes that’s true. However, I recently read an interesting Fast Company article stemming off the disasters of Japan, about how social media is used in a crisis, and its potential for good or bad. We’ve seen recently in Indonesia, where earthquakes, a tsunami, and volcanic eruptions destroyed a significant part of the area’s infrastructure, how locals are using Twitter to coordinate relief effort. Tweets go out saying help is needed to deliver a food drop, and within minutes there is a caravan of volunteers. While it’s still too early to say  what role if any social media will have in Japan’s disaster relief, we are seeing high usage since the moment the earth began to shake. It is understandably the easiest way to alert your family and friends that you are safe, but even the prime minister, himself, gives updates using Twitter. We see statements of encouragement, warnings from those far away, but also rumors. David Zax, the article’s author, references a map of how radiation could spread throughout China that has gone viral. No one is sure if it is real, but that it is out there makes it something of concern. Zax therefore raises the question, “What happens to truth when filtered through social media in a time of crisis?” Similarly, to the Indonesian crisis, citizens of the Middle East are using Twitter and Facebook to arrange their large protests. Both systems were significant in the uprising that lead to the resignation of Egypt’s despot, and social media has long played a role in the underground opposition movement in Iran. It’s obvious how social media has been useful in these cases, because it is so hard to prevent the public’s involvement in it. While these are great examples of how social media allows good to overcome, there is nothing that preventsit from being used to shape our perception in the opposite direction. Since companies are finding their new media campaigns so successful, what would prevent someone from creating an elaborate campaign that could be used for something bad? Zax therefore asks the question, “Are social media sites inherently a force for good?” In the end, of course, the medium cannot be accountable for the user. The best thing we can do is  just continue doing what we’ve been doing since the emergence of social media and the internet as a whole for that matter–digging through the unnecessary and fake information.
item.excerpt:encoded: The inherent nature of Social Media.

item.title: Design Thinking is a Failure?
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
This week, one of Design Thinking's long time advocates, Bruce Nussbaum, declared the practice a failure and announced he was moving on to a new conceptual framework for expressing the value of design. Bruce is a former assistant managing editor for Business Week and a Professor of Innovation and Design at Parsons The New School of Design. In the article Bruce says,
Design Thinking broke design out of its specialized, narrow, and limited base and connected it to more important issues and a wider universe of profit and non-profit organizations. I believe the concept of Creative Intelligence expands that social engagement even further. So what is Creative Intelligence, or CQ? Above all, CQ is about abilities. I can call them literacies or fluencies. It is about more than thinking, it is about learning by doing and learning how to do the new in an uncertain, ambiguous, complex space--our lives today.
At the center of Bruce's disillusionment with Design Thinking is the business community's high valuation of the process versus the intended deliverable: creativity. Business latched onto Design Thinking as a method to achieve innovation without all the messy, emotional, conflict-driven circularity of creative work. But this preference for work-flow and avoidance of creative-stretch, crippled Design Thinking  projects and produced far more failures than successes. Though I agree with Bruce's observations, I disagree with his solution, Creative Intelligence. Jumping into yet one more buzz-word filled concept instead of staying engaged with, and defending, the Design Thinking process appears to devalue the future contributions designers can make to business and social problems. The gem of Bruce's article, and candid assessment of the design practice, is an interview with IDEO's Tim Brown. Tim, a thought-leader and advocate for design's promise, talks frankly and optimistically about the results we've achieved so far and the opportunities that lie ahead. From the comments Bruce Nussbaum, received it's clear his article has stirred up new debates. In a time when the collective design-consciousness of the business community and the global community continues to rise, the conversations are sure to be lively.

item.title: To be or not to be... on Facebook
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: Christoph Kappes, former Pixelpark CEO, who now is holding this position at Fructus, deals with this conundrum on an article for German online publication W&V. Kappes stands on his ground when he says that “Not every brand has to have a Facebook FanPage. Facebook is not as helpful to brands as one believes”. He boldly points out that, no matter how many Facebook users ‘liked’ your page, results do not always follow. “There are brands that don’t need to keep in touch with the client. Some of these survive because they’re distant, like upper-class brands.” Brands who have outstanding client following and fidelity, like Apple, don’t need to use social media to connect with their clients “their raison d’être is to be exclusive and have a mystic halo”. The Facebook FanPage model is more about trying to get more clicks and fans, not about coming up with new and efficient ways of communicating with the consumer. The bottom line is: you don’t have to be on Facebook just because all the cool kids are in there, sometimes it’s good to be asocial. Read it all here.

item.title: France bans Facebook and Twitter mentions on TV and radio
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
A couple days ago the French government banned the words ‘Facebook’ and ‘Twitter’ from being said on radio and TV. This ban originates on a 1992 decree which considers mentioning services by the name as a form of advertising.

Christine Kelly, spokeswoman for the Conseil Supérieur de l’Audiovisuel (CSA), the government broadcasting authority, stated: “Why give preference to Facebook, which is worth billions of dollars, when there are many other social networks that are struggling for recognition? This would be a distortion of competition. If we allow Facebook and Twitter to be cited on air, it’s opening a Pandora’s Box. Other social networks will complain to us, saying ‘Why not us?’”.

So now news anchors have to go with “Follow me on... social networks” which seems kind of a really odd thing to say.

What do you think?

Does a "Follow me us Twitter." at the end of a media spot constitute advertising?

Extracted from an article on ZdNet.com

item.title: Gareth Kay: Think small
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: Big problems don’t need big solutions. They need long lasting ideas build of small ideas. These small ideas are made of small actions that change people’s behavior and make a brand feel personal. To succeed in these actions you have to be humble, empathetic and interested in people’s lives. This is what Gareth Kay explained throughout several posts on his blog a month ago after a presentation gave during Future Flash 2011 in Collingwood, Canada. On his last ramble, as he says, he sets up a list of things agencies need to do to make small ideas happen. 1. Build brands from the bottom up rather than the top down. Brands are build in people’s minds like a bird’s nest, little by little. 2. Be useful, interesting, entertaining and playful in the service of people. 3. Think about what communication strategy can learn from user experience design. The best customer service is the one that’s not noticed. 4. Do something and interesting things will happen. Be action oriented rather than word oriented. 5. Build a culture of experimentation, not planning. Do and learn, not learn and do. Try to do new things and see where they get you. 6. Realize perfection is the enemy. Things are not always ready when they need to be ready. We need to realize that good     enough is more often than not good enough. 7. Be rewarded for good behavior. Do your job the best you can, don’t try to get as much undeserved money from the     client as you can. These seven points are a great advice to the industry but also a list of everything that this industry often does wrong. Hero has followed Gareth's work since we met at Boulder Digital Works. He's one of our favorite sharp thinkers. Gareth brings clarity and a comforting sense of do-able to world of advertising and branding. You can follow Gareth Kay’s thoughts on his personal blog.

See all five ads here.

item.title: Evernote Peek. Playing, learning, peeking.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
While flying back from SXSW, Evernote VP of Marketing Andrew Sinkov and Evernote CEO Phil Libin where playing around with an iPad Smart Cover and they realized how this cover could be used to create what eventually it would be, Evernote Peek; an iPad app that acts just like a set of flashcards, but also it can turn into a game. When I was in high school I used to study my History notes by acting up the war events. It’s common knowledge that you learn things easily when you are having fun with it; and this is the purpose of Evernote Peek. Lift the first flap of the Smart Cover and you’ll see a question. Lift the second flap and you’ll see it’s answer. If you answered correctly tap the ‘Correct’ checkbox, otherwise, the ‘Incorrect” one. To go to the next question, close the Smart Cover. The app keeps score and will let you re-test your wrong answers. The great twist of Peek is using the Smart Cover as an input device for the app. I wonder if Apple engineers intended this use. If they did, I’m doubly impressed. The Peek app is another demonstration of mobile design’s unlimited potential. As a design studio working in the field it’s inspiring to see such innovation.

Trying Peeking At Hero's Internet Slang Quiz.

To have more fun with the app, we created our own Internet Slang Quiz. If you’re an Evernote Desktop app user, you can DOWNLOAD our quiz and import it into your notebooks. Once you link your Evernote account to the Peek app our quiz, along with your other notebooks, will be available under the Add button. OSSIM!

item.title: Heineken Star Player, live soccer guessing app.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XP5yySEZub8 What would make the soccer Champions League even more fun and exciting? A good answer would be to create a competition within the competition. And that’s exactly what the Heineken Star Player app pretends. It doesn’t re-invent the wheel, that’s true, but, with this app, soccer fans can share their knowledge of the game with other users. It shifts their "sharing of soccer" from real world to online and from online to the app. Even more important than sharing this knowledge is the competition element. Users get points with each good guess they make around different aspects of the game. Predicting a goal will happen on the next 30 seconds will get you more points than predicting a save. Points are always an incentive and a reward. In this case, they are the mark of a true soccer fan. There's always the uncertainty over whether this app will get a solid user base and if the company will be able to sustain their interest a few games into the competition. But, being an official sponsor of the Champions League we're pretty certain they will. Boy, we can't wait for the 2011-2012 Champions League to start.

item.title: Dot spots
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=24sO7uOQPxg Since last year, Dairy Farmers of Canada, has been airing this unusual campaign created by Due North Communications. Through really short commercials they are creating a strong brand image. They have already aired over 200 different pieces. Steadily creating new ones makes the campaign stay fresh and keep attracting people’s interest because, they will probably never see the same commercial more than twice. This campaign is a good example of how Gareth Kay believes advertising should be nowadays. How, out of small executions, you can get a big campaign that is sustainable for the brand. And if you make a mistake, no problem, you got another 199 executions to make up for it.

item.title: The Cloud. How will we love thee?
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: We took a look at Jon Pareles’ article on the NY Times regarding the, much desired, imminent arrival of Cloud services. He points out some fairly interesting ideas about the pros and cons of this long-waited service. Jon Pareles has been a music critic for 30 years and, because of that, he has an amount of albums that would make most of music lovers happy forever. But this also has a downside, he has “amassed more vynil, CDs and digital files than he knows what to do with”. And “periodic weeding will not keep up with the 20-30 discs that arrive in the daily mailbag”. Situations like this make the Cloud a need, a salvation to those who are suffering from musical Diogenes syndrome. However, as Pareles accurately points out “iTunes Match as currently described will in effect launder music that was copied illicitly, replacing home-ripped files with standardized, good quality 256 kbps iTunes Plus AAC files. But now record labels and publishers will receive 70 percent of Apple’s fee.” This is the underlying double standard iTunes Match is really offering. That clean start is probably the main feature that will make Apple’s platform succeed over Google’s or Amazon’s cloud services. Apple lets users play the role of that convicted fellow who gets wired and, in exchange, goes away scot-free. Don’t get us wrong, the Cloud is necessary. It frees hard drive space, works as a backup in case of computer catastrophe, and gives mobile devices that extra space that we never thought we’d need but, in the end, we do. As Pareles says “it’s charming to see an album that’s nowhere in my phone’s memory available for listening with the option to copy selected files for offline play”. And this charming option complements the “instant gratification” smartphones give to the user. Listening to music has become more about convenience and less about quality. We now laugh at the 80s boombox-on-the-shoulder trend. This has been replaced with in-ear earphones and a small electronic device with great storing space, which is, as we said, convenient. Now that the space problem is solved, people like Pareles can “turn to something even more intractable: the time to listen to” all our music. We need the i30-hours-a-day. You can read Jon Pareles' original here. This article was written in its entirety listening to music. Mp3 files, not vinyl. We’re not that fancy here.

item.title: Connect your marketing with your audience.
item.dc:creator: Jeff

item.title: The industry formerly known as advertising.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: The advertising industry is changing. This is a fact everyone in the industry is aware of. The change has been caused by the internet, computer and mobile technologies which have fragmented the media and shifted power from the advertisers to the people. The dominance of traditional interruption advertising is over and the new dynamics of search, engagement and sharing have taken over. And, truth to be told, this change excites us at Hero because it broadens the landscape of tactics, opens up opportunities for smaller players and makes human ideas, not media scale, the most powerful force in the market. Another powerful force which has contributed to this change is social media. Social media is becoming more important with every passing day and everyone wants to be a part of it. Even though it’s not a suitable medium for every business. This change in the industry’s landscape isn’t just because of social media, of course, but it’s safe to say that social networking has modified the dynamics when communicating with the consumer and public opinion. At Hero Design Studio, we’ve been following, for some time now, the opinions of a few of our industry’s favorite sharp thinkers about this shift advertising is taking. And now it has come the time to share them with you, fellow subscriber/follower/random passerby, because they are interesting. Classic advertising is dying Advertising “is quickly evolving into a new industry that maybe it shouldn’t even be called advertising”, says freelance Creative Director and strategic brand consultant Tom Geoghegan. Now it’s all about connecting with the consumer, but also about immediacy. “In today’s media, responding to a socially relevant conversation 2-4 weeks after the fact is almost always too late. Sometimes, a day is just too late”, as Geoghegan states. Instantly responding to what’s going on in the market or in society is a practice that can be quite expensive, therefore, you’re most likely to see big companies doing this on the mass media. They do so because they’re the ones who have the infrastructure and the money for it. Small and medium-sized companies have heard about the change in advertising but they aren’t confident in the new ways they need to connect with customers – they need new strategies, they need new tactical frameworks. These companies haven’t re-imagined their teams to include the networks and connectors they need and often they don’t understand what customers want from them. Identifying your customer is Advertising, Marketing, and Design’s 101. Just as important as this, is to “stop communicating products and start making communication products”, Gareth Kay’s mantra. Nowadays, “you solve brand problems by solving people problems”. Provide a useful service to your customer – or, as said, not even to the customer but to the people – and chances are that your message will come across nicely. Succesfully communicating increases the odds of your company improving its brand image and being remembered when potential customers have the choice to purchase, or not, your product or service. As Faris Yakob argues, “you can’t change belief, but you can change behavior” towards your brand. The flip side of the coin All of the stated above is positioned from the business-to-consumer point of view. But, what about the ad agencies and their relation with the client? Well, in the words of Made by Many’s Founder, William Owen, “selling creativity doesn’t cut it anymore, you have to sell effectiveness and measurability” by showing audience statistics, getting recorded results and, of course, a monetary return to the campaign investment. Long gone is the time when companies spent money on the basis of faith. The requirements now include that you provide reliable data proving that the communication strategy you used is worth the money. The reason of this is, of course, the media cluttering. So the basic premise now is: if you can’t come up with something creative, at least make it effective. Sounds good enough doesn’t it? Well, for making it effective, most of the time the industry resorts to run the ad more times, which ends up in a nice contribution to cluttering the media. So, be creative, be effective, solve people’s problems and connect with them. Hard? Yeah. But if this industry was easy it would be called valet parking.

item.title: Blink and you'll miss it.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: It looks like the Dairy Farmers of Canada ad campaign has set a precedent. Maybe the economical crisis is making creative minds sharper when it comes to get the point across as fast as possible and still deliver strong content. Or maybe it's just the ability to extrapolate the product's qualities into attractive, one-of-a-kind commercials. Anyway, this Audi campaign focuses on some of the A1 model's characteristics, making clear the fact that you don't have to buy a big car to enjoy big features. Audi can "condense" all those features into a tiny car, and they show them one by one. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=18qFVo0XZoI http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DS5hlstlnh8 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uSfBl3S7Lpg

item.title: The paperless business card.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: What would you do if you wake up one day and realize you’re surrounded by more paper than is needed? Well, you could do as Barcelona-based guerrilla marketing agency Poko did and come up with the business card stamp. “We never run out of business cards. And we feel better about ourselves”, says Joan Alvares, Poko founder. He has been stamping everything he was able to, which makes for some fun stories: “At the Mobile World Congress, after requesting a meeting with the business executive of a well-known multinational corporation, we shook hands and he said: - I’ll check my schedule tomorrow and I’ll propose a date for the meeting. Give me your email. - I’m afraid I already did. At home he got it, while washing his hands.” “At the Entrepreneurs Fair, a designer asked me for a business card so he could send me his portfolio. - Excuse me, but you gave me your metro ticket... - Yeah, when are you coming to the office? That day, he left his motorbike at home and use the public transport.” “A friend complimented me after running into each other at an important festival held at Barcelona’s Contemporary Culture Center: - I didn’t know you were sponsoring the event... - Neither did I... Yup, I was bored so I stamped a bunch of three-page leaflets”.   As seen on www.yorokobu.es

item.title: Design Thinking still lives!
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Design Thinking is a topic we like to follow. We only wish we could have attended this recent conference. from Imprint
The New York City Chapter of the Industrial Designers Society of America and innovation consultancy Fahrenheit 212 collaborated last month on a very successful event entitled, Design Thinking: Dead or Alive?A stellar panel of voices, including Stephan Clambaneva, Debera Johnson, Cliff Kuang, Bill Moggridge, Mark Payne, Helen Walters and moderator Allan Chochinov, gathered at Fahrenheit 212’s expanding offices to discuss design thinking.
Read more: Still Alive! Highlights from Design Thinking: Dead or Alive? — Imprint-The Online Community for Graphic Designers

item.title: Augmented political reality
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: The use of Augmented Reality nowadays is pretty much limited to funny/entertaining stuff . It’s treated more as a game or a cool feature rather than something profitable. Moving away from these uses, the German Green Party’s Berlin chapter — alongside with Augmented Reality company Metaio — has launched a mobile app that lets users discuss about the city’s environmental issues. Aiming the mobile device to a point of interest will make an overlay pop up showing other users' thoughts over that issue  allowing the user to share their own opinion about it. In addition to this, when users aim the app to one of the Green Party’s billboard, one of the party candidates will discuss in depth the matter portrayed on the billboard. This is a really interesting take on new ways of maximizing the reach of a political campaign and the approach to hesitant voters outside the mass media. Especially having in mind the high number of political parties in European countries, where most of the time parties don't get the majority vote as it's scattered. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gdlqtLVdTpw   As seen on www.readwriteweb.com

item.title: For those who deserve a beer. Heineken BFF.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: People don’t want me to say what I’ll do. They want me to do what I say! — Jeff Winger (Community) http://vimeo.com/27276017 Ace app concept created by Ogilvy NY art-direction intern Glen Hansen and copywriter Otilia Dobrea. If this became a real app with a record, we could tell apart big-mouthed fellas from those who stay true to their word. No more sighs with a glimpse of hope in getting something from them besides that nice pat on the back. Knowing that, that ice cold, refreshing, tasty beer they promise is as metaphorical as hell freezing over.

item.title: The story of Aaron the barber
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: http://vimeo.com/27602708 It looks like the internet sites such as Reddit have something else to offer besides LOLCats, memes, quirky news and trolling. They also can spin acts like the one that happened during the London riots. Seven days ago, Reddit was the one to first raise concern about the looting 89-year-old London barber Aaron Biber suffered at his shop. Aaron had run that barbershop for 41 years and now he was forced to shutter because he didn’t have insurance and couldn’t afford the repairs. This story seemed to connect with several redditors — reddit.com users — who found in Aaron the tale of an all-timer middle-low class man with an iconic business. A barbershop that would be sad to see disappear  just because some rioters thought it was fun to trash and loot. Right after the post being upvoted, redditors started looking for ways of sending Aaron some money to help him straighten out the situation. This action was picked up by three interns at London ad agency BBH Barn and, through a blog and a more than decent social media response, they managed to raise £35,000 ($57,000) in only  three days. After that period of time they closed the fund said Aaron had “more than enough to get himself back up and running”, states the blog. The rest of the fund left after fixing the barbershop will be distributed to help the businesses near Aaron’s that were also affected by the riots. Of course, Aaron Biber’s barbershop wasn’t the only one affected by London riots and it won’t be the last disgrace to happen. But this is just one of those nice stories where a simple spark on the internet lights a fire.

item.title: The Client's Wife
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: Young & Rubicam Argentina has created this fun (and fairly hard to beat) game inspired by old-school space shooters like Galaga or Space Invaders. You play as a fearless creative team who goes on a quest to create an ad campaign. They'll face terrible enemies such as a fierce account manager army, hordes of evil cryptic briefs or narrow-minded-I-want-a-bigger-logo clients. And this is only the beginning of this epic 8-bit adventure that will take you to the depths of the advertising Hades. Welcome to The Client's Wife.

item.title: Who's that guy that just liked my brand?
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: So yeah, you have a pretty well-fanned Facebook page but you may don't really know how they interact with your brand nor how you interact with them, how strong is that engagement. Moontoast has created this infographic explaining how the different ways of "liking" affect the communication with your audience and their friends, the data you get from this "likers", and it also shows the different fan profiles you can find on Facebook. See the infographic after the jump.

item.title: InNOvation in advertising
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Innovation is a dangerous goal in advertising. Obviously, the industry has to keep on moving forward, and needless to say is that you can't show the audience the same stuff all the time because they grow tired of it. You can justify it by saying that it is coherent with your message, but that's not enough. If you're going to try to stand out in the clutter that the airwaves are and get possitive feedback, you have to do it right.
Here's an example of what we believe is unnecessary, this campaign for Kia Picanto. Was it really necessary to spend 1,800 hours painting 900 fingernails for a 30-second stop motion piece?
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9A_TX-rlfvU
They can always say that they "outbest anyone at putting a whole lot of effort in getting a bunch of stuff in a small place". But, having at hand graphic design tools that can do the same work faster… It's a waste of money and manpower that could be invested in other campaign components.
The campaign has worked pretty well online, you can't deny that — over 3M views on Youtube — but we would like to take a look at how it has boosted Kia's sales in Korea.

item.title: Delicious, crafty animation for Chipotle.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: Delicious and crafty work by director John Kelly for Chipotle Mexican Grill (our local). We'll file this in the "I Wish We Will Get To Do That One Day" bin. Kelly has recently released a behind the scenes video and stills of the production process. The craft, creativity and innovation of the piece is evident.

item.title: The Dutch Stutter Foundation asks us to be patient
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded: We love when design is key in effective communication. And it's definitely a plus when it delivers social responsible content. So, of course, we love this billboard set in Amsterdam by agency Y&R Not Just Film —with the collaboration of out-of-home advertising company JCDecaux— for the Dutch Stutter Foundation It's clever, visual, simple, and contains a powerful message.

item.title: Internship opening: Designer
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Learn the skills you need, to be more than an intern. Be challenged by diverse range of digital and traditional projects. Earn a position on a focused, hard-working creative team. Take an espresso break at 3PM everyday. =============================== You need creativity, great ideas, crappy ideas, the ability to think like the market, the ability to fill a blank page with a design that reflects the brief and the ability to express yourself well through writing. If you can illustrate, hand-letter or draw with any modicum of skill, bonus points for you. You need to be a web native, know how it works and how to make it work for you. You need a basic knowledge of HTML, CSS, Javascript and PHP. You need to have good instincts for designing user experiences and one eye on the trends and technologies that are pushing the web forward. If you have substantial page markup or coding experience, bonus points for you. You need to have a basic knowledge of print design and print production. You need to be comfortable with your design software and striving to master it. If you have done some video production, have motion graphic or video editing experience, then bonus points for you. =========================== Start = immediately End = By Dec 31st Hours = preferably full-time, but negotiable. Compensation = Our camaraderie and mentoring.
How to apply: Send us: • A short missive about who you are and what what makes you tick. • PDF of portfolio samples or a link to your portfolio site.Send to: jeff@herodesignstudio.comIf we dig your work and your writing, we'll call you in for an interview.

item.title: Internship opening: Copywriter
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Learn the skills you need to a copywriter, in real-life. Be challenged by diverse range of marketing and content writing. Be a part of concept development and creative strategy. Stroll leisurely for an espresso each day at 3PM. ================================== You need creativity, big ideas, small ideas, the ability to think visually and the ability to fill a blank page with copy that fulfills the brief. You need to know the difference between a benefit and a feature. If you have research experience and know how to dig up facts, bonus points for you. You need to be a web native, know how copy connects to SEO practices and SEO results. You need to be able to generate a list of keywords around a topic and weave them into body copy. If you have experience writing for Google AdWords, bonus points for you. You need a basic knowledge of social media, how to share and promote content across the web. If you write a blog of your own which you share through Twitter and Facebook, bonus points for you. ========================== Start = immediately End = By Dec 31st Hours = preferably full-time, but negotiable. Compensation = Our camaraderie and mentoring.
How to apply: Send us: • A short missive about who you are and what what makes you tick. • PDF of portfolio samples or a link to your portfolio site.Send to: jeff@herodesignstudio.comIf we dig your work and your writing, we'll call you in for an interview.

item.title: Subscribe to influential people's gifts
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
As Quarterly.co put it themselves:

Quarterly Co. is a subscription service that lets you receive awesome things in the mail. You can subscribe to people you find interesting and, once every three months, they will send you a package right to your doorstep. (...) Quarterly is all about the contributors who are choosing new and exciting things to send to you.

We really dig the idea of receiving physical thoughtful gift — for which you pay a subscription fee in advance, of course. In these days, you really get excited when something besides bills and catalogues arrives in the mail. Don't deny it, when you order online you keep checking the tracking number for updates, we all do. And you know exactly what you're going to get. Now imagine you don't know what it'll be but it's something from an artist you picked, that you are interested in his/her thoughts and how will those translate into a quarterly curated piece. That's quarterly.co, good ideas in your mail.

item.title: Hero and HubSpot
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Hero is happy to announce its new partnership with HubSpot, an all-in-one inbound marketing software that provides users the tools to get found, convert customers and analyze success.

HubSpot is a practical application of Hero’s philosophy, that the best marketing is less about pushing and interrupting and more about attracting and engaging customers.

Hero chose HubSpot as the clear leader in inbound marketing software. Not only does the software platform integrate a company’s website, blog, social media, email campaigns and landing pages; it offers analytics at every level.

In its 2011 ROI report, HubSpot's customers averaged four times more traffic and 25 times more leads than they did prior to using HubSpot.

In the coming weeks, Hero clients will see HubSpot in action as Hero integrates its own site into the platform, while the Hero team works toward becoming a HubSpot Certified Partner.

item.title: Stop thinking like you.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Many marketers suffer from a common problem: they know their products too well and can’t see them as a stranger to the brand would. Instead, they tell the customer the ‘what’ when they could be winning them over with the ‘why.’ Hero principal, Jeff Mason, discusses ways marketers can avoid those blind spots and employ empathy in order to better communicate with their customers.

Ask yourself these questions when creating your marketing message: Why was this product created? Origin storytelling is a powerful way to communicate your brand’s purpose and earn customer appreciation. Who is your customer and how did they find you? Remember where your audience is coming to you from, and talk to them accordingly. What language are you speaking? This is part two of remembering your audience. If what you sell is specific to a certain type of customer, then speaking in technical terms is appropriate; but if you are competing on the grocery shelf, use layman’s terms. What does your product do? This is the piece of the puzzle that is most often overlooked in advanced planning stages. Get back to the basics. The most effective way to sell your product is by simply letting it speak for itself.

Other videos in this series:

Marketing Success: Connect with your audience. The Project Brief: Clients, your designer needs your expertise.

Hero Smarts is a video blog series where we share things we've learned about design, marketing and business.
item.category: be a stranger to the brand

item.title: The Science of SEO
item.dc:creator: lara
item.content:encoded: We really like the twist on the traditional infographic in Search Engine Land’s recent collaboration with Column Five in the “Periodic Table of SEO Ranking Factors”. SEO is often mystifying, bewildering; it can be confusing, feel like you’re using some sort of black magic with the final results somehow coming together like a mad scientist’s lab experiment. This graphic is awesome in its layout of the fundamental elements of a marketing plan and how each element fits together. We’re given modern marketing factors, visually arrayed like your traditional periodic table, which can react to each other like your standard organic elements of Hydrogen and Oxygen. The right combination can bring about evolutionary, even sustaining results—for example, H20— while the wrong combination could be detrimental to your SEO plan. Think less of explosives and more of a lackluster fizzle. In the table we get to see how all of the marketing gears relate, attract and react in combination, and exactly where they belong in classification within the sea of on or off-page factors of content marketing. SEO is difficult because it requires a substantial investment of work over time that pays off when efforts are focused. With the countless factors that all contribute towards marketing your business, it’s always helpful to have reference to what matters most and this table is a great visual to remind us of our focus.
item.category: Periodic Table of SEO Ranking Factors

item.title: In the Digital Age, Words Still Matter
item.dc:creator: lara
item.content:encoded:
As professionals, reading and writing is second nature. We jot down notes, digitally send documents, and bring ideas to life through conversation. We don’t always acknowledge the actual medium of the written word due to its ready availability and everyday usage. This disregard, however, proves that written language is the basis of all communication and commerce, and is key to the development of relationships with your clients and the global online community. From email to pamphlets, and brand identity to website programming, words are they key to our online engagement, our primary interactions with them being in content creation and communicating or navigating through search engines.

Words Are Universal, Practical and Economic

The written language is the oldest, yet still most valuable currency in today’s communication age, as it weighs in with a sense of economy and practicality in any market. The written and spoken word stands as the oldest form of communication and remains as the primary foundational tool for communicating any subject in any medium in the modern day.

The shift from solely print culture to an integration of online media has caused the markets of advertising and design to abandon the dependence on traditional print marketing and move towards the digital medium. Advertising was originally thought to be independent from the Internet, yet now, the two have become one.  Marketers now must be all the more creative to be seen and heard, incorporating both graphics and language into the grand expanse that the Internet has become. Yet, regardless of their angle, all creatives start and end each project with language, anchoring it to practical and realistic usage through conversation.

Engaging With the Language of the Web Think about your interaction with the Internet today. To get to this article, you most likely used a search engine like Google to look up “Hero Design Studio”, “Denver Marketing Agency”, “language in content marketing” or something of the like that brought you to this page. Thanks to our universal lexicon as literate human beings, the vocabulary that defines a brand or concept is available through characters of the written language.  Words are the fabric of the SEO network, itself. We wouldn’t be able to interact within Internet without them, as our use is dependent upon written words of the human language. Inbound marketing is entirely dependent upon written content, as SEO is the vehicle that allows small businesses to engage in the online market. When written well, and aligned with your optimized keywords, your written content is an effective marketing tool that can positively result in better SEO rankings and heightened organic traffic. Taking advantage of the written language, well-composed writing that uses a diverse vocabulary appropriate to your brand identity will undoubtedly aid in maintaining your overall clout. Language is a means for you to communicate with your client, and conversely, for them to communicate back to you. Through written content, you can tailor your site and blog to be woven into the language of the greater web. In effectively using an appropriate yet unique vocabulary, you can craft your brand identity into keyword phrases that are presently untapped reservoirs of wealth in the online search engine lexicon. Online Content Creation All online content, whether it is composed through code or conversationally written, is made up of language. Though your personal linguistic ability may not include HTML or SQL, coding and programming languages do carry weight for many individuals. Just as writers, journalists and poets manipulate words to create meaning, online programmers manipulate language to create commands for the communication of the Internet. You may think that this use of language is entirely different; yet, translation of linguistic characters in this way is exactly how we are able to communicate ideas online. The progression to the digital space would never be possible without the foundation of written language. We are able to view media created through codes and graphics accompanied by written explanation—all of which broadens our learning experience as users.  While we remain as learners, we can use these tools to better educate our clients, optimize SEO, and create a niche for our brands in the appropriate field that they’ll be found. Words are key because they have the ability to communicate globally, regardless of technological abilities on either end of a conversation. Their economy survives any educational or financial background, and can withstand hundreds of years of existence thanks to documentation. Look at the archive on any website and you’ll find months, even years, of past written information, all of it organized through language that has been translated to the Internet’s native programming to optimize information for users like us.
item.category: Importance of writing in Inbound Marketing

item.title: Inbound and Outbound Marketing: Do You Know the Difference?
item.dc:creator: lara
item.content:encoded: An online business or a physical business with an online presence has the option of using outbound or inbound marketing to bring in customers. The two concepts are worlds apart. First, let's define the outbound marketing concept as traditional advertising, (i.e., television and radio ads, direct mail, billboards, newspaper and magazine advertising are all outbound advertising avenues to get you in front of customers). Conversely, inbound marketing brings customers to you. Let's Go Fishing The reason why inbound marketing is different can be illustrated by a fishing trip. Outbound marketing can be compared to a fishing trip in which you stock up on multiple rods and reels (media). Some work, some don't.  Some fish strike the bait, the other rods and reels never get a bite. You've succeeded but only partially, and you’ve invested a lot of time and money into all of the equipment. With inbound marketing, you simply use a single net. First, you've saved money. Secondly, you don't have to run from one rod to another, trying to figure out which bait works best. You simply pull in the fish that found their way into your net. The net is your website and its contents. It takes less effort and less expense to produce better results. The net doesn’t necessarily have to be enormous or grandiose, but making sure that are no holes and that it isn’t rusty are key to attracting and catching the leads you want. Why Inbound Marketing Is Different Inbound marketing brings customers who are looking for your product or service to you. It's done with effective search engine optimization, convincing content, and a website that invites the customer to step inside your virtual business and take a look around. These are customers who found you instead of you finding them. Typically these customers have an idea of what they’re searching for on the Internet and if they find your site, there is a good chance they landed there with intent. Once found, a website with good landing pages, quality and informative content converts visitors to sales leads and then eventually into customers. As professionals, however, we have to remember that, just like fishing, patience is a virtue. Using optimization and other platforms such as social media sites broadens the funnel of website traffic. By pulling more visitors in to the top of your funnel you educate and inform them with solid content. This content promotes the value and benefits of your merchandise or service and nurtures sales leads into a position of trust and comfort, thus pulling more traffic from the top of the funnel to the bottom. Magnetizing Your Website By using best social website practices, engaging content and valuable information, your conversion rate from visitor to lead to customer increases. As website traffic builds, periodic analysis of data, evaluation what is working well and what can work better is assessed. Tweaking the website, receiving input from social media sites to make small, subtle improvements will convey your message more clearly. This heightens sales, your branding message and increases exposure; making your site a magnet for sales. The Return On Investment The return on the initial investment is a basic reason why inbound marketing is different. Your site, social media connections, quality content and optimization work 24/7. They're constantly pulling in visitors. No billboards, television commercials or newspaper ads can produce the same results for the same costs. Inbound marketing is also more flexible. When circumstances change, your site can react almost immediately to fit the circumstances, the times and the social or market conditions. Print and film media do not convert as quickly or inexpensively. Let's Get Started As a digital agency, we at Hero believe that it is important to acknowledge both outbound and inbound marketing, however, we’re obviously strong advocates for the benefits that can rise out of inbound strategies. For every client, including ourselves, we make a point to fully embrace every opportunity within inbound marketing that will help a business thrive. We enjoy engaging with client brands to better understand how together, we can work to create a marketing strategy that is both compelling and attractive—a net that won’t just catch one fish, but will have the whole pond talking. Are you looking to expand your marketing plan but don’t quite know how to take hold of digital strategies? Contact us to learn how we can build a net and increase your catch.
item.category: Pull Customers In With Inbound Marketing

item.title: So Drawn. So Long. So Good.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
This video hit my inbox one day after reading Khoi Vinh’s lament about the absence of illustration in online publications, The Sad Story of Illustration on the Web. The two seem to counter balance each other. The video was created for We Cut Corners, an Irish duo, for the song Pirates Life. It was produced over two months, hand-drawn frame-by-frame, using just markers and paper. That is rarefied territory. Few illustrators, or digital artists, today will ever experience a commercial project requiring such a sustained creative effort. Not for lack of desire or an absence of craft, but because rarely does the market fund it. I agree with Vinh's observation, that the drive of digital media leaves no time and no budget for conceptual, commissioned illustration. I also agree with what he sees as the effect of this reality.
It’s unfortunate, because it means as content consumers we’re deprived of a really valuable mode of communication that has been a longstanding partner of some of the best content that publishing has ever produced.
And so, with my cynical acceptance of illustration's decline and Vihn's words still ringing in my ears, I watched Kijek and Adamski's video and felt renewed. The clarity, the playfulness, the humanity reminded me that illustration is going nowhere. It's alive and thriving. Just not in its old locales. If digital pubs won't invest the time needed for illustration, then so be it. That ship has sailed. Readers who want that will go elsewhere or give up. Meanwhile, beautiful illustration is thriving in new places, in new media and is bringing a deeply satisfying touch of hand, manos, to our digital world. Hero doesn't do video, yet, but we do a lot of illustration. If you want to bring a hand-quality to your next design project, give us a call.

item.title: 3 Online Marketing Mistakes You're Making Right Now
item.dc:creator: lara
item.content:encoded:
Mistakes are never intentional, especially when it comes to marketing your own business. Yet, with what seems like a never-ending amount of the “little things” to remember when keeping your business organized online, it’s easy to miss something important as the playing field seems to be constantly changing. We’ve compiled a short list of mistakes that even the pro’s make, so if you’re guilty of any one of these, you’re not alone.  Mistake #1: Poor Keywords That Aren’t Well-Aligned with Your Content At this point, you’re probably sick of hearing about the importance of keywords and the substantial impact they can make. However, researching your keywords will probably be forever crucial, as these short phrases are the foundation to all aspects of your business’s online presence—from your site, to your blog, SEO, PPC advertising, and social media engagement. Anyone can become an expert at using keywords. It’s simply a matter of research and practice through trial and error. Keyword research is essentially the study of how words become more or less saturated in your business’s SEO market and gain or lose relevancy depending on how that word is adopted within search engines. Keeping all of this up to date will undoubtedly keep the right traffic coming towards your site, as nobody wants to arrive at an outdated site. Keyword research is an ongoing process and you must stay active with it, otherwise you’ll likely fall behind and your site won’t match the keywords you’ve structured it around. Mistake #2: Poorly Optimized Landing Pages, Advertising and Calls to Action
  • Landing Pages and Analytics: A well-designed landing page will grant your business credibility, as it shows that your site not only has more than two pages—a contact page and home page—but also that you put the time and energy into creating multiple pages because you care enough about your business to do so. Your thorough planning and advocacy for your brand could, in turn, result in gaining outside advocates. A well-designed landing page will say more than the obvious “contact us” or “click here to buy from us.” Your landing page should address the needs of your prospects. A lot of the time online businesses can seem extremely impersonal, because people don’t take the time to actually understand and make relevant landing pages that speak directly to the needs of their clients.
  • Calls to Action: Links for calls to action and landing pages should without a doubt meet their promise of providing more information to prospective clients. If that landing page doesn’t link to what was promised upon being clicked, the chances of your visitor going elsewhere heighten drastically. The analytics of landing pages are key to long-term success with clients, as promised offers on your site or blog are the first step of your potential client’s interaction with you as a company. Similarly, you need to be creating multiple offers through your CTA’s and landing pages. When there are multiple offers on the table, your business doesn’t look like a one-trick pony and your lead may realize that more than one of your offers can apply to their needs.
Mistake #3: Poor Result Tracking Result tracking is essentially about being in control of your website. Proper management of your online content will result in better control of your business. If you're not using even basic analytics you’re doing your business a disservice. Great analytical tracking (and understanding which data to read) will help you recognize how to improve, even if your success rate is on an exponential incline. One of the major online marketing mistakes is the value of quantity over quality. You want visitors to explore further than your home page, portfolio, and contact page; you want them to act upon your landing pages and engage with your offers. Tools like Hubspot’s Keyword Grader, or Google Adwords are a great and easy to use place to gauge your site analytics and see where people are looking, who your competitors are, and often times, you’ll find something that you had no idea was out there. Are You On Track? As writers and designers at Hero, we’re constantly working to edit and revise our work to make it better. We return to finished projects, updating them so that our keywords and landing pages all match the medium and client needs in the ever-changing world of the Internet. We love the trial and error process that it takes to get a website running the way it should be, and we’d love to help get yours to the level that it could, or should I say should, be. If you’re curious about your analytics, landing pages or even keywords, contact us. We’d love to talk.

item.title: Search Is Highly Influential On The Buying Process.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
When not busy sending us search results, Google spends its time researching the market and buying behavior. What their latest findings show is that search, online-research and social sharing combined have become the most influential sector of your marketing ecosystem. So influential, in fact, that in 2011 people's pre-purchase research included 10.4 sources. Up from 5.4 sources in 2010. What we're now seeing now is a fundamental re-wiring of the buying process.

The Buying Process is the series of steps people go through when making a making a purchase. The primary steps include awareness, interest, research, trial, purchase and evaluation. In the traditional mental marketing model, outbound marketing was relied on to build awareness and drive people to a retail outlet. The retail environment has been called the First Moment of Truth. What Google's research has shown is that search, online-research and social sharing have so changed the buying process that a new mental model has emerged, one that includes a Zero Moment of Truth. Watch Google's video. With changes in buyer behavior and the average person's buying process, marketers have to adjust. The adjustments most effective  in today's brave search world will involve keyword optimized web content that connects marketers with buyers when they are searching for information, reviews and recommendations during the Zero Moment of Truth. The strategy that we use to create effective marketing for today's buying process in inbound marketing.
Rather than doing outbound marketing to the masses of people who are trying to block you out, We advocate doing "inbound marketing" where you help yourself "get found" by people already learning about and shopping in your industry. In order to do this, you need to set your website up like a "hub" for your industry that attracts visitors naturally through search engines, the blogosphere, and social media.1
With inbound marketing's strong focus on keywords and search optimization it's perfectly inline with the new mental marketing model revealed by Google's research. Make sure your company is being found by buyers when they are most active in their online research. Add inbound strategies to your marketing mix and be ready for today's search-savy buyer. Let's Get Started As a digital agency, we believe in the benefits that can rise out of inbound strategies. For every client, including ourselves, we make a point to fully embrace every opportunity within inbound marketing that will help a business thrive.  Are you looking to expand your marketing plan but don’t quite know how to take hold of digital strategies? Contact us to learn how we can you adapt your marketing to the new buying process.

item.title: Jeff Mason. Making Things andSolving Problems.
item.dc:creator: Jeff
item.content:encoded:
Jeff Mason, Hero Design Studio's Principal and Design Director,
talks about how he came to run
a design studio and how his business experience makes him
a better designer.

Making things and solving problems.

Like many in the creative industries, I've taken a winding path to land where I am today—the owner and director of a design studio. I started in music, then move to product design, graphic design, web design and finally, now, some combination of all. In the current state of design and marketing, I find all my past experiences converging into a skill-set of creative communication. Gone are the mass media days of my youth. They've been replaced by connected conversations and branded experiences that rely on a designer's empathy and a craft-person's skill. Design is not fine art, it's problem solving and I focus on solving the problems of business. Over the years I've managed several businesses and have a true appreciation for the determination and effort required to make one successful. My business experience is an integral part of the work Hero does for its clients. I never forget that our job is to create a positive business result, to help our clients grow and contribute to their success. In the last year, the way in which all this fits together has become clearer to me and defines the services my studio offers. Design is about making things that communicate with people and help them solve problems. Marketing is about putting design to work to build brands, connect with customers and create business growth.

Why the name Hero?

I'm often asked why I named the studio Hero. The name came from the idea of an everyday hero—someone who sees what needs to be done and does it. We do our fair share of up-front thinking, but we always bring it back to doing. Getting things done, measuring results and making it better is what our work is all about.

What do I love?

I love collaboration, coffee, craft beer and food. Luckily all those thing go well together, so my life has a nice synchronicity.

What causes do I support?

I'm a big supporter of bi-lingual education and international studies. My daughter attends a language immersion school and I see first-hand the power of cross-cultural communication and global awareness. Our children are growing up in a world with far fewer boundaries and infinitely more connections. I think language and culture studies foster empathy and community. And that, I believe, promotes peace, hope and prosperity for all of us.

What's next for Hero?

Hero has long been a proponent of Design Thinking—using both intuition and analytics to create design solutions. It's at the core of how we approach our design work. This year we've strengthened our marketing services by adopting Inbound Marketing methodologies and partnering with the HubSpot. You'll see a lot of writing on our blog about these marketing strategies and how they connect to our design work. As we see it, design is about making things, marketing is about putting them to work. Anyone who wants to know more about me or Hero should connect with me on Linkedin. Cheers, Jeff Connect with me on Linkedin.
